Document Title: Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs) in Early Gait Recognition of Parkinson’s Disease: An Ensemble Learning Approach
Authors: Z. Zheng; C. Gong; X. Zhao; L. Zhang; L. Meng; L. Chen; C. Cui; W. Chen; F. He
Author Affiliations: Faculty of Medicine, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Future Research Institute, China Mobile Research Institute, Beijing, China; School of Automation, Beijing Information Science and Technology University, Beijing, China; The Affiliated Brain Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University, Guangzhou, China; Faculty of Medicine, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China; Department of Neurology, Tianjin Huanhu Hospital, Tianjin, China; Future Research Institute, China Mobile Research Institute, Beijing, China; School of Automation, Beijing Information Science and Technology University, Beijing, China; Faculty of Medicine, Tianjin University, Tianjin, China
Publication Title: 2024 8th Asian Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ACAIT)
Abstract: Real-time home healthcare represents a typical application scenario for future sixth-generation (6G) communication technology. Parkinson's Disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that significantly affects motor functions, including gait, leading to shuffling steps, festinating gait, and freezing of gait. Early diagnosis of PD is crucial, as timely intervention can mitigate disease progression. This paper presents an ensemble learning approach to improve early recognition of PD through gait analysis. We construct a dataset of over 2,000 samples from both PD patients and healthy controls, utilizing 6-axis Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs) to capture gait metrics. An adaptive ensemble learning model, incorporating five different classifiers, is trained on this dataset, achieving an F1 score of 96.54% and an accuracy of 96.61% in distinguishing PD patients from healthy controls.
Author Keywords: ensemble learning;gait analysis;inertial measurement units (IMUs);parkinson's disease;sixth-Generation communication technology (6G)
IEEE Terms: 6G mobile communication;Adaptation models;Measurement units;Accuracy;Parkinson's disease;Refining;Inertial navigation;Communications technology;Ensemble learning;Gait recognition

Document Title: Early Parkinson’s Disease Detection via Touchscreen Typing Analysis using Convolutional Neural Networks
Authors: D. Iakovakis; S. Hadjidimitriou; V. Charisis; S. Bostanjopoulou; Z. Katsarou; L. Klingelhoefer; S. Mayer; H. Reichmann; S. B. Dias; J. A. Diniz; D. Trivedi; R. K. Chaudhuri; L. J. Hadjileontiadis
Author Affiliations: Signal Processing and Biomedical Technology Unit, Telecommunications Laboratory, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece; Signal Processing and Biomedical Technology Unit, Telecommunications Laboratory, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece; Signal Processing and Biomedical Technology Unit, Telecommunications Laboratory, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece; Department of Neurology, Hippokration Hospital, Thessaloniki, Greece; Department of Neurology, Hippokration Hospital, Thessaloniki, Greece; Department of Neurology, Technical University Dresden, Dresden, Germany; Department of Neurology, Technical University Dresden, Dresden, Germany; Department of Neurology, Technical University Dresden, Dresden, Germany; Faculdade de Motricidade Humana, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal; Faculdade de Motricidade Humana, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal; International Parkinson Excellence Research Centre, King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, London, United Kingdom; International Parkinson Excellence Research Centre, King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, London, United Kingdom; Signal Processing and Biomedical Technology Unit, Telecommunications Laboratory, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, Greece
Publication Title: 2019 41st Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
Abstract: Parkinson's Disease (PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder worldwide, causing both motor and non-motor symptoms. In the early stages, symptoms are mild and patients may ignore their existence. As a result, they do not undergo any related clinical examination; hence delaying their PD diagnosis. In an effort to remedy such delay, analysis of data passively captured from user's interaction with consumer technologies has been recently explored towards remote screening of early PD motor signs. In the current study, a smartphone-based method analyzing subjects' finger interaction with the smartphone screen is developed for the quantification of fine-motor skills decline in early PD using Convolutional Neural Networks. Experimental results from the analysis of keystroke typing in-the-clinic data from 18 early PD patients and 15 healthy controls have shown a classification performance of 0.89 Area Under the Curve (AUC) with 0.79/0.79 sensitivity/specificity, respectively. Evaluation of the generalization ability of the proposed approach was made by its application on typing data arising from a separate self-reported cohort of 27 PD patients' and 84 healthy controls' daily usage with their personal smartphones (data in-the-wild), achieving 0.79 AUC with 0.74/0.78 sensitivity/specificity, respectively. The results show the potentiality of the proposed approach to process keystroke dynamics arising from users' natural typing activity to detect PD, which contributes to the development of digital tools for remote pathological symptom screening.
IEEE Terms: Keyboards;Pipelines;Parkinson's disease;Convolutional neural networks;Tools;Monitoring
Mesh_Terms: Early Diagnosis;Humans;Motor Skills;Neural Networks, Computer;Parkinson Disease;Sensitivity and Specificity;Smartphone;User-Computer Interface

Document Title: Objective quantification of upper extremity motor functions in Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale Test
Authors: X. Jia; N. Duroseau; V. Chan; C. Ciraco; R. Wang; S. M. Nia; K. Ho; J. P. Govindavari; F. Delgosha; T. Chan; K. M. Pergament; B. Krishnamachari; A. Farajidavar
Author Affiliations: The Integrated Medical Systems (IMS) Laboratory, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; The College of Osteopathic Medicine, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; The College of Osteopathic Medicine, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; The College of Osteopathic Medicine, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; The Integrated Medical Systems (IMS) Laboratory, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; IMS Laboratory and with the College of Arts and Sciences at the New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; New York Institute of Technology, Old Westbury, NY, US; The College of Osteopathic Medicine, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; School of Engineering and Computing Sciences, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; The College of Osteopathic Medicine, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; New York Institute of Technology, Old Westbury, NY, US; The College of Osteopathic Medicine, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA; The Integrated Medical Systems (IMS) Laboratory, New York Institute of Technology (NYIT), Old Westbury, NY, USA
Publication Title: 2014 36th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society
Abstract: Two tri-axial accelerometers were placed on the wrists (one on each hand) of the patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) and a non-PD control group. Subjects were asked to perform three of the upper extremity motor function tasks from the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) test. The tasks were: 1) finger tapping, 2) opening and closing of palms, and 3) pronation-supination movements of the forearms. The inertia signals were wirelessly received and stored on a computer for further off-line analysis. Various features such as range, standard deviation, entropy, time to accomplish the task, and maximum frequency present in the signal were extracted and compared. The results showed that among the studied population, “standard deviation”, “range”, “entropy”, “time” and “max frequency” are the best to worst features, respectively, to distinguish between the non-PD and PD subjects. Furthermore, using the mentioned features, it is more probable to distinguish between the non-PD and PD subjects from tasks 2 and 3 as opposed to task 1.
IEEE Terms: Feature extraction;Standards;Accelerometers;Entropy;Electronic mail;Parkinson's disease
Mesh_Terms: Accelerometry;Aged;Aged, 80 and over;Humans;Middle Aged;Parkinson Disease;Severity of Illness Index;Task Performance and Analysis;Wrist

Document Title: Parkinsons Disease Progression Prediction using Advanced Machine Learning Techniques
Authors: T. Bhattacharya; K. T. Thomas; L. Mathew
Author Affiliations: Department of Data Science, Christ (Deemed To Be) University, Pune, India; Department of Data Science, Christ (Deemed To Be) University, Pune, India; Department of Data Science, Christ (Deemed To Be) University, Pune, India
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Electrical Electronics and Computing Technologies (ICEECT)
Abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative condition that affects people over time and significantly lowers their quality of life. Patients with PD experience both motor and non-motor symptoms. Through clinical evaluation, the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) is used to quantify the severity of Parkinson's disease. No definitive diagnostic tests for PD currently exist. Emerging machine learning techniques show potential to forecast future UPDRS scores for making informed medical decisions and enable better disease management. This paper studies research leveraging proteomic data to forecast PD prognosis, focusing on advanced machine learning techniques like CatBoost Regressor, ElasticNet, XGBoost Regressor, RandomForest Regressor, ExtraTrees Regressor and DecisionTree Regressor.
Author Keywords: parkinsons’ disease;machine learning;unified parkinson's disease rating scale (UPDRS);proteomic data;CatBoost regressor;extraTrees regressor
IEEE Terms: Proteins;Parkinson's disease;Peptides;Proteomics;Biomarkers;Predictive models;Robustness;Planning;Prognostics and health management;Mutual information

Document Title: An Emerging Era in the Management of Parkinson's Disease: Wearable Technologies and the Internet of Things
Authors: C. F. Pasluosta; H. Gassner; J. Winkler; J. Klucken; B. M. Eskofier
Author Affiliations: Department of Molecular Neurology, University Hospital Erlangen, Erlangen, Germany; Department of Molecular Neurology, University Hospital Erlangen, Erlangen, Germany; Department of Molecular Neurology, University Hospital Erlangen, Erlangen, Germany; Department of Molecular Neurology, University Hospital Erlangen, Erlangen, Germany; Digital Sports Group, Pattern Recognition Laboratory, Department of Computer Science, Friedrich Alexander University Erlangen-Nürnberg (FAU), Erlangen, Germany
Publication Title: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
Abstract: Current challenges demand a profound restructuration of the global healthcare system. A more efficient system is required to cope with the growing world population and increased life expectancy, which is associated with a marked prevalence of chronic neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease (PD). One possible approach to meet this demand is a laterally distributed platform such as the Internet of Things (IoT). Real-time motion metrics in PD could be obtained virtually in any scenario by placing lightweight wearable sensors in the patient's clothes and connecting them to a medical database through mobile devices such as cell phones or tablets. Technologies exist to collect huge amounts of patient data not only during regular medical visits but also at home during activities of daily life. These data could be fed into intelligent algorithms to first discriminate relevant threatening conditions, adjust medications based on online obtained physical deficits, and facilitate strategies to modify disease progression. A major impact of this approach lies in its efficiency, by maximizing resources and drastically improving the patient experience. The patient participates actively in disease management via combined objective device- and self-assessment and by sharing information within both medical and peer groups. Here, we review and discuss the existing wearable technologies and the Internet-of-Things concept applied to PD, with an emphasis on how this technological platform may lead to a shift in paradigm in terms of diagnostics and treatment.
Author Keywords: Wearable technologies;Internet of Things;Parkinson’s disease;knowledge discovery;patients;Internet of things (IoT);knowledge discovery;parkinson's disease (PD);patients;wearable technologies
IEEE Terms: Parkinson's disease;Biomedical monitoring;Internet of things;Wearable sensors

Document Title: Assessment of Parkinson's Motor Severity by Multi-feature and Multi-scale Motion Convolutional Neural Network with Positional Encoding
Authors: Y. Zhou; L. Xiao; X. Su; X. Xu
Author Affiliations: School of Communication and Information Engineering, Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Chongqing, China; Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Publication Title: 2023 4th International Seminar on Artificial Intelligence, Networking and Information Technology (AINIT)
Abstract: Parkinson's disease is one of the most common neurodegenerative diseases. Its main clinical manifestations are a variety of movement disorders, including abnormal gait, which seriously affect the performance of motor function, leading to shaking hands at rest, bradykinesia, myotonia, and difficulty in maintaining postural balance. The current work focuses on the methods of wearable devices and non-wearable devices to evaluate sports injuries. However, the network models based on the Movement Disorder Society Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS) to quantify the severity of Parkinson's disease injuries have problems such as incomplete generalization of input features, insufficient feature extraction of network models, and imbalance between recognition accuracy and model size. A lightweight and high-precision convolutional neural network model is essential for accurate and quantitative assessment of disease progression and for slowing or preventing further disease progression. Regarding the above issues, we use a computer vision-based model to observe video recordings of the human body, extract their 3D body skeletons, track them through time, and input them into our proposed a Triple-feature Triple-motion Convolutional Neural Network (PE-TTNET) with Positional encoding for training. We position encode the triple scale features and classify the gait severity of PD patients based on MDS-UPDRS. The experimental results indicate that PE-TTNET achieved better results compared to previous network models in testing the clinical dataset we collected, with higher Fl-score and average accuracy in classifying the severity level of Parkinson's disease.
Author Keywords: Convolutional Neural Network;3D body skeletons;Parkinson's disease
IEEE Terms: Three-dimensional displays;Parkinson's disease;Computational modeling;Wearable computers;Feature extraction;Bones;Encoding

Document Title: Classification Using Radial Basis Function for Prediction of Parkinson's Disease
Authors: M. M. Umar; S. Naaz
Author Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, School of Engineering Sciences and Technology, New Delhi, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, School of Engineering Sciences and Technology, New Delhi, India
Publication Title: 2022 IEEE 3rd Global Conference for Advancement in Technology (GCAT)
Abstract: Parkinson's is a disease of the nervous system which is a progressive in nature. The main cause of this disease is damaged neurons in the brain which are responsible for generating dopamine. This results in people not being able to control their body part movements which affect their day to day activities badly. More than 6 million individuals worldwide have Parkinson disease. These symptoms keep growing over time, till the patient realize they have Parkinson's disease. This paper aims to employ Radial Basis function for predicting of presence or absence of Parkinson's disease using the Motor Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale and Total Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale score. An accuracy of 97% percent has been obtained in this work.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's disease;radial basis function;Total UPDRS;MOTOR UPDRS;K means clustering

Authors: T. Soni; D. Gupta; M. Dutta; B. V. Kumar; H. MuhamedAle
Author Affiliations: Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; School of Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence, SR University, Warangal, Telangana, India; Department of Computers Techniques Engineering, College of Technical Engineering, The Islamic University, Najaf, Iraq
Publication Title: 2025 4th OPJU International Technology Conference (OTCON) on Smart Computing for Innovation and Advancement in Industry 5.0
Abstract: Progressive neurodegenerative illness Parkinson's disease (PD) is typified by non-motor symptoms that seriously impair quality of life as well as motor symptoms including tremors, stiffness, and bradykinesia. Good management and treatment of Parkinson's disease depend on an early and precise diagnosis. used a number of machine learning techniques to divide the voice samples into groups with and without Parkinson's Disease. At an accuracy of 88.8%, the K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN) method outperformed the other models examined. Strong training and validation procedures were made possible by the large dimensionality and variety of the features in the dataset, underscoring the promise of speech signal analysis for Parkinson's disease early diagnosis and monitoring. We show that KNN is effective in managing complicated, high-dimensional biomedical information and offer a viable path for non-invasive Parkinson's disease diagnosis tools.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's disease;Machine Learning;KNN;Decision Tree;Healthcare

Document Title: Association of Neurological Family Health History in Parkinson's Diseases
Authors: S. Gupta; S. Bose; V. Majhi
Author Affiliations: Amity School of Engineering and Technology, Amity University Uttar Pradesh, Noida, India; Inrec Productive Research Solutions and Services Private Limited, Domkal, India; Amity Innovation and Design Centre, Amity University Uttar Pradesh, Noida, India
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Brain Computer Interface & Healthcare Technologies (iCon-BCIHT)
Abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder primarily affecting elderly people. While the exact cause of idiopathic PD is still unknown, a family history of the condition has been observed in 10 to 15 percent of cases. In addition, Mendelian inheritance patterns are seen in about 5% of cases. In this study we aimed to assess the significant correlation between the development of PD with individual's family's neurological health history. Here we have considered total 13 specific questionnaire related to the subject's neurological family history. The statistical attribution has been made for both uncategorized and categorized by sex. There are notable correlations observed between the PD patient and the history of neurological disorders in family members. Here, we saw that most of them-such as anxiety, depression, Alzheimer's disease, and Parkinson's disease-are protective in nature, while very few-such as the multiple sclerosis (OR-3.25) of the paternal grandmother, the dystonia (OR-1.92) maternal grandmother, and the schizophrenia (OR-1.65) of the mother-act as risk factors. These figures also demonstrate how important family history is in determining the likelihood that the next generation will develop Parkinson's disease.
Funding Information: The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research;
Author Keywords: Parkinson's Disease;Health History;Family Health History
IEEE Terms: Neurological diseases;Correlation;Parkinson's disease;Statistical analysis;Schizophrenia;History;Alzheimer's disease;Older adults;Next generation networking;Diseases

Document Title: Suppression of Beta Oscillations in a Parkinson's Disease Model by Dynamic Delayed Feedback Control
Authors: S. Ji; Y. Che; J. Yang; S. Li; R. Wang
Author Affiliations: Tianjin Key Laboratory of Information Sensing & Intelligent Control, School of Automation and Electrical Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology and Education, Tianjin, P. R. China; Tianjin Key Laboratory of Information Sensing & Intelligent Control, School of Automation and Electrical Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology and Education, Tianjin, P. R. China; Tianjin Key Laboratory of Information Sensing & Intelligent Control, School of Automation and Electrical Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology and Education, Tianjin, P. R. China; Tianjin Key Laboratory of Information Sensing & Intelligent Control, School of Automation and Electrical Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology and Education, Tianjin, P. R. China; School of Information Technology Engineering,Tianjin University of Technology and Education, Tianjin, P. R. China
Publication Title: 2023 42nd Chinese Control Conference (CCC)
Abstract: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is the main technique for the treatment of Parkinson's disease (PD) at present. In this paper, we propose a DBS scheme based on dynamic delayed feedback control for suppression of beta oscillations in a PD model. First, we simulate normal and PD states of cerebral cortex basal nucleus thalamic neural circuit using a simplified subthalamic nucleus (STN)-external globus pallidus (GPe) neural network computational model. Then, a dynamic delayed feedback control scheme is designed to optimize the DBS technique for suppression of beta oscillations in PD state. Finally, two evaluation indexes, inhibition index and control energy index, are proposed to evaluate the control performance. It is found that, in a large range of control parameter space, the dynamic delayed feedback control scheme based DBS can effectively suppress the oscillations in the beta band of Parkinson's state.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's disease;Deep brain stimulation;Subthalamic nucleus (STN)-external globus pallidus (GPe);Dynamic delayed feedback
IEEE Terms: Parkinson's disease;Computational modeling;Satellite broadcasting;Aerospace electronics;Brain modeling;Feedback control;Indexes

Document Title: Early detection of Parkinson's disease through shape based features from 123I-Ioflupane SPECT imaging
Authors: N. A. Bhalchandra; R. Prashanth; S. D. Roy; S. Noronha
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India; Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India
Publication Title: 2015 IEEE 12th International Symposium on Biomedical Imaging (ISBI)
Abstract: Detection of Parkinson's disease (PD) at an early stage is important for effective management and for initiating neuroprotective strategies early in the therapeutic process. Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) using 123I-Ioflupane (DaTSCANTM, GE Healthcare; also known as [123I]FP-CIT) have shown to be a sensitive marker for PD even in the early stages of the disease. In this paper, we carry out image processing to compute shape-based features which are radial and gradient features from SPECT scans from 163 early-stage PD and 187 healthy normal subjects obtained from the Parkinson's Progression Markers Initiative (PPMI), and use them along with the striatal binding ratio (SBR) values, also provided by the PPMI as features to classify between the two using Discriminant Analysis and Support Vector Machine (SVM). We observe a high accuracy of 99.42% in classification. It is inferred that such models can aid clinicians in the early diagnostics of PD.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's disease;Computer-aided early detection;Pattern analysis;Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA);Support Vector Machine (SVM)
IEEE Terms: Single photon emission computed tomography;Feature extraction;PD control;Support vector machines;Accuracy;Parkinson's disease

Document Title: PdAssist: Objective and quantified symptom assessment of Parkinson's disease via smartphone
Authors: Y. Chen; X. Yang; B. Chen; C. Miao; H. Yu
Author Affiliations: The Beijing Key Laboratory of Mobile Computing and Pervasive Device, Beijing, China; The Beijing Key Laboratory of Mobile Computing and Pervasive Device, Beijing, China; Beijing Key Laboratory for Parkinson's Disease, Beijing, China; Joint NTU-UBC Research Centre of Excellence in Active Living for the Elderly (LILY), Nanyang Technologies University, Singapore; The Beijing Key Laboratory of Mobile Computing and Pervasive Device, Beijing, China
Publication Title: 2017 IEEE International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedicine (BIBM)
Abstract: In clinical settings, the assessment of Parkinson's disease (PD) mainly depends on the doctor's experience and observation. Such assessment often lacks of unified standards and may result in varied diagnoses among different doctors. To cope with this problem, we propose an objective and quantified symptom assessment tool of PD on mobile devices, based on the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS). The mobile PD assessment tool, PdAssit, assesses PD symptoms by actively delivering six tasks and generates scores equivalent to UPDRS using machines learning models. PdAssit is applied in three essential applications, including medication response detection, symptom self-tracking and diagnostic assistance. The feasibility and effectiveness of PdAssit is demonstrated through clinical experiments.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's disease;smartphone;symptom assessment
IEEE Terms: Feature extraction;Parkinson's disease;Sensors;Accelerometers;Time-domain analysis;Tools

Document Title: From Data to Diagnosis: Utilizing Deep Belief Networks for Early Parkinson's Disease Detection
Authors: S. Mehta; S. Khurana
Author Affiliations: Centre for Research Impact & Outcome, Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology Chitkara University, Rajpura, Punjab, India; Chitkara Centre for Research and Development, Chitkara University, Himachal Pradesh, India
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Emerging Technology (Global AI Summit)
Abstract: Parkinson's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive deterioration of symptoms, whereby the afflicted individuals' standards of living are significantly diminished. Ideally, identification is the best practice for control and intervention; nevertheless, traditional approaches used in diagnosing may fail to detect the disease during its early stage. This paper aims to determine whether DBNs are suitable for detecting PD early since they can assess complicated and high-dimensional medical information. During the DBN modelling, the data used here were trained and tested using publicly available datasets, and the accuracy level recorded was 92 percent. In comparison, the sensitivity was 90 percent, and the specificity was 94 percent. The ROC-AVC of the timing of task execution was calculated to be 0. 95 percent in the diagnostic capacity, which indeed indicates the high level had been maintained. According to the above results, the DBN model provided superior performance to other diagnostic methods, which include a low false-negative rate. Traditional techniques, where the diagnosis depends on a doctor's assignment and imaging techniques, are usually less accurate and take more time to detect diseases early. It is crucial to note that this research proves the DBN model's feature of recognizing little deviations that hint at early-stage Parkinson's disease, making for a robust and practical diagnostic application. In clinical practice, the DBN model has been used numerous times, all of which pointed to the identification of early-stage Parkinson's disease patients who had not been diagnosed at all or were diagnosed with other disorders.
Author Keywords: Deep Belief Network;Convolutional Neural Networks;Parkinson's Diseases;Deep Learning;Decentralized Machine Learning;Privacy-Preserving AI
IEEE Terms: Solid modeling;Accuracy;Sensitivity;Parkinson's disease;Solids;Data models;Timing;Reliability;Medical diagnostic imaging;Standards

Document Title: Flexible Forearm Triboelectric Sensors for Parkinson's Disease Diagnosing and Monitoring
Authors: D. F. V. A; T. He; J. -M. Redoute; C. Lee; M. R. Yuce
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering, Monash University, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering and Center for Intelligent Sensors and MEMS (CISM), National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; Department of Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering, Monash University, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering and Center for Intelligent Sensors and MEMS (CISM), National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; Department of Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering, Monash University, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia
Publication Title: 2022 44th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine & Biology Society (EMBC)
Abstract: Existing approaches that assess and monitor the severity of Parkinson's Disease (PD) focus on the integration of wearable devices based on inertial sensors (accelerometers, gyroscopes) and electromyographic (EMG) transducers. Nevertheless, some of these sensors are bulky and lack comfortability. This manuscript presents triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs) as an alternative stretchable sensor solution enabling PD monitoring systems. The prototype has been developed using a triboelectric sensor based on Ecoflex™ and PEDOT:PSS that is placed on the forearm. The movement of the skin above the forearm muscles and tendons correlates with the extension and flexion of fingers and hands. This way, the small gap of 0.5 cm between the polymer layers is displaced, generating voltage due to the triboelectric contact. Signals from preliminary experiments can discriminate different dynamics of emulated tremor and bradykinesia in hands and fingers. A modified version of the TS is integrated with a printed circuit board (PCB) in a single package with signal conditioning and wireless data transmission. The sensor platforms have demonstrated a good sensitivity to PD symptoms like bradykinesia and tremor based on the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (MDS:UPDRS).
IEEE Terms: Performance evaluation;Transducers;Parkinson's disease;Wearable computers;Voltage;Muscles;Rigidity

Document Title: A Deep Learning Hybrid Model for Parkinson's Disease Diagnosis Based on Electroencephalogram Signals
Authors: J. Li; X. Cao; B. Hou; X. Li; Q. -A. Ding
Author Affiliations: College of Electronic and Information Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, China; College of Electronic and Information Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, China; West Coast Campus, The Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University, Qingdao, China; West Coast Campus, The Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University, Qingdao, China; College of Electronic and Information Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, China
Publication Title: 2023 17th International Conference on Complex Medical Engineering (CME)
Abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) often unable to be detected at an early stage because some of its symptoms are confused with aging, which makes the professional neurologists' clinical diagnosis limited. This study proposes a deep learning hybrid model based on resting-state electroencephalogram (EEG) to help neurologists diagnose the PD in a correct and timely manner. The model, consisting of convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract characteristics and recurrent neural network (RNN) to capture time dependence, has been evaluated on two public datasets (UNM dataset and UI dataset). The result indicates that the presented hybrid model has a very high accuracy on the public datasets. Thus, the model is expected to be a reliable and non-invasive technique for PD detection using EEG.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's disease;Deep learning;Convolutional neural network;Electroencephalogram
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Training;Accuracy;Recurrent neural networks;Parkinson's disease;Brain modeling;Feature extraction

Document Title: Quantitative assessment of Parkinson's disease with multiple wearable devices
Authors: Q. Bai; H. Zhang; C. Mao; L. Li; Q. Yu; B. Xu; T. Shen; C. Liu; S. Wang
Author Affiliations: Chinese Academy of Science, Suzhou Institute of Biomedical Engineering and Technology, Beijing, China; Department of Neurology, Soochow University, Suzhou, China; Department of Neurology, Soochow University, Suzhou, China; Chinese Academy of Science, Suzhou Institute of Biomedical Engineering and Technology, Beijing, China; Chinese Academy of Science, Suzhou Institute of Biomedical Engineering and Technology, Beijing, China; Chinese Academy of Science, Suzhou Institute of Biomedical Engineering and Technology, Beijing, China; Chinese Academy of Science, Suzhou Institute of Biomedical Engineering and Technology, Beijing, China; Department of Neurology, Soochow University, Suzhou, China; Chinese Academy of Science, Suzhou Institute of Biomedical Engineering and Technology, Beijing, China
Publication Title: 2016 IEEE 13th International Conference on Signal Processing (ICSP)
Abstract: With the aging of the population, Parkinson's disease (PD) is increasing and severely threating to human life and health. Quantitative assessment of the symptoms in PD is the key for precise diagnosis and treatment and essential for long term management over years. Currently, the evaluation of the symptoms in PD mainly relies on Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS), which is affected by the subjective judgment of the clinicians. In this paper, we developed a new method for quantitative assessment of the motor symptoms in PD with multiple wearable devices. The method was used in conjunction with UPDRS assessment, and movement monitoring during sleep.

Document Title: Body-Sensor-Network-Based Kinematic Characterization and Comparative Outlook of UPDRS Scoring in Leg Agility, Sit-to-Stand, and Gait Tasks in Parkinson's Disease
Authors: F. Parisi; G. Ferrari; M. Giuberti; L. Contin; V. Cimolin; C. Azzaro; G. Albani; A. Mauro
Author Affiliations: CNIT Research Unit of Parma and the Department of Information Engineering, University of Parma, Parma, Italy; CNIT Research Unit of Parma and the Department of Information Engineering, University of Parma, Parma, Italy; Xsens Technologies B.V., Enshede, AN, The Netherlands; Research & Prototyping, Telecom Italia, Turin, Italy; Department of Electronics, Information, and Bioengineering, Politecnico di Milano, Milano, Italy; Division of Neurology and Neurorehabilitation, Istituto Auxologico Italiano, IRCCS, Piancavallo, (VB), Italy; Division of Neurology and Neurorehabilitation, Istituto Auxologico Italiano, IRCCS, Piancavallo, (VB), Italy; Department of Neurosciences, University of Turin, Turin, Italy
Publication Title: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
Abstract: Recently, we have proposed a body-sensor-network-based approach, composed of a few body-worn wireless inertial nodes, for automatic assignment of Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) scores in the following tasks: Leg agility (LA), Sit-to-Stand (S2S), and Gait (G). Unlike our previous works and the majority of the published studies, where UPDRS tasks were the sole focus, in this paper, we carry out a comparative investigation of the LA, S2S, and G tasks. In particular, after providing an accurate description of the features identified for the kinematic characterization of the three tasks, we comment on the correlation between the most relevant kinematic parameters and the UPDRS scoring. We analyzed the performance achieved by the automatic UPDRS scoring system and compared the estimated UPDRS evaluation with the one performed by neurologists, showing that the proposed system compares favorably with typical interrater variability. We then investigated the correlations between the UPDRS scores assigned to the various tasks by both the neurologists and the automatic system. The results, based on a limited number of subjects with Parkinson's disease (PD) (34 patients, 47 clinical trials), show poor-to-moderate correlations between the UPDRS scores of different tasks, highlighting that the patients' motor performance may vary significantly from one task to another, since different tasks relate to different aspects of the disease. An aggregate UPDRS score is also considered as a concise parameter, which can provide additional information on the overall level of the motor impairments of a Parkinson's patient. Finally, we discuss a possible implementation of a practical e-health application for the remote monitoring of PD patients.
Author Keywords: Body Sensor Network (BSN);Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU);Parkinson’s Disease (PD);Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS);Leg Agility (LA) task;Sit-to- Stand (S2S) task;Gait (G) task;Body sensor network (BSN);gait (G) task;inertial measurement unit (IMU);leg agility (LA) task;Parkinson's disease (PD);sit-to-stand (S2S) task;unified Parkinson's disease rating scale (UPDRS)
IEEE Terms: Kinematics;Feature extraction;Parkinson's disease;Body sensor networks

Document Title: The Impact of Deep Belief Networks on the Early Diagnosis of Parkinson's Disease
Authors: S. Vats; S. Mehta
Author Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University; Adjunct professor, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India
Publication Title: 2024 5th International Conference on Electronics and Sustainable Communication Systems (ICESC)
Abstract: PD, or Parkinson's Disease, is a neurodegenerative disorder that commonly disorients movement abilities. Hence, correctly identifying this disease at its early stages is essential for appropriate treatment. The conventional diagnostic methods are usually not able to accurately identify the early signs of Parkinson's disease (PD) as they depend on the visible symptoms and the patient's self-reports. The study suggests deploying a deep belief network (DBN) method, considered a highly advanced machine learning algorithm, which is more of a memory structure capable of learning deeply and hierarchically. Their study implied the use of a DBM model for a diverse data set of 500 PD subjects suspected to have disease in its early stage. The dataset contains medical records, speaking analysis, audio recordings of subjects, and biometric monitoring. The model was trained using a two-phase training approach. The first phase is an unsupervised pre-training process to learn general characteristics. The results were very encouraging: the DBN model achieved an accuracy of 93%, yielded a sensitivity of 90%, specificity of 93% and AVC of 0. 7. 97. The performance of these measures was better than that of the ordinary diagnostic methods, which had an accuracy of 85%, a sensitivity of 80%, a specificity of 85% and an AVC of 0.85.
Author Keywords: Deep Belief Network;Convolutional Neural Networks;Parkinson Diseases;Deep Learning;Decentralized Machine Learning;Privacy-Preserving AI
IEEE Terms: Biometrics;Training;Accuracy;Sensitivity;Parkinson's disease;Biological system modeling;Neural networks;Data models;Monitoring;Medical diagnostic imaging

Document Title: Fox- Based Feature Selection Algorithm for Detection of Parkinson's Disease
Authors: N. Singh; S. Sinha; L. Singh
Author Affiliations: Amity Institute of Information Technology, Amity University, Noida, Uttar Pradesh, India; Amity Institute of Information Technology, Amity University, Noida, Uttar Pradesh, India; Dept. of Computer Science (AI- ML), KIET Group of Institutions, Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh, India
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (CICN)
Abstract: This research presents a FOX based feature selection method for detecting Parkinson's disease (PD). PD is a progressive neurological ailment that requires early detection for optimal treatment. The proposed method improves diagnostic accuracy by picking a small subset of discriminative features from high-dimensional data, resulting in better model interpretability and computational economy. Extensive research on several PD datasets reveals that the approach outperforms in both feature selection and disease detection accuracy. Comparative analyses using existing machine learning approaches demonstrate the efficacy of the FOX method. Furthermore, the selected features provide important insights into the underlying biomarkers associated with PD pathogenesis. The proposed FOX-based algorithm provides a viable option for early PD detection, with practical applications for improving patient outcomes through timely intervention and individualized treatment regimens.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's Disease;Fox- Optimization Algorithm;Feature Selection;Machine Learning Models
IEEE Terms: Machine learning algorithms;Accuracy;Parkinson's disease;High dimensional data;Computational modeling;Soft sensors;Pathogenesis;Feature extraction;Optimization;Computational intelligence

Document Title: An Automatic Detection Method for Bradykinesia in Parkinson's Disease Based on Inertial Sensor
Authors: H. Juanjuan; Y. zhiming; W. Jianguo; L. Bochen; Y. Xianjun
Author Affiliations: Institute of Intelligent Machines, CASHIPS University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Institute of Intelligent Machines, CASHIPS University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Institute of Intelligent Machines, Hefei Institute of Physical Science, CAS, Hefei, China; Institute of Intelligent Machines, Hefei Institute of Physical Science, CAS, Hefei, China; Institute of Intelligent Machines, Hefei Institute of Physical Science, CAS, Hefei, China
Publication Title: 2020 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Electronics Technology (ICET)
Abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) and Parkinson's syndrome (PS) are common neurodegenerative diseases that occur in the elderly. Bradykinesia is a typical motor symptom of PD and PS.This paper is mainly based on the inertial sensor to collect the upper limb movement signals of Parkinson's disease, extract the corresponding characteristics, and use the neural network multi-layer perceptron (MLP) model to automatically detect the bradykinesia of Parkinson's disease. The experimental results show that the classification accuracy of neural network multi-layer perceptron algorithm for Parkinson's disease and normal subjects is over 90%, and the classification accuracy for normal subjects, Parkinson's disease and Parkinson's syndrome is 85%.This study shows the feasibility of using wearable devices to quantitatively evaluate the motor symptoms of patients with Parkinson's disease and Parkinson's syndrome, and the extracted quantitative indicators and detection methods have certain reference value for future related studies.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's diseases;inertial sensor;UPDRS;RMS;artificial neural network

Document Title: Assessment of Motor Impairments in Early Untreated Parkinson's Disease Patients: The Wearable Electronics Impact
Authors: M. Ricci; G. Di Lazzaro; A. Pisani; N. B. Mercuri; F. Giannini; G. Saggio
Author Affiliations: Department of Electronic Engineering, University of Rome “Tor Vergata,”, Rome, Italy; Neurology Unit, Department of Systems Medicine, University of Rome “Tor Vergata,”, Rome, Italy; Neurology Unit, Department of Systems Medicine, University of Rome “Tor Vergata,”, Rome, Italy; Neurology Unit, Department of Systems Medicine, University of Rome “Tor Vergata,”, Rome, Italy; Department of Electronic Engineering, University of Rome “Tor Vergata,”, Rome, Italy; Department of Electronic Engineering, University of Rome “Tor Vergata,”, Rome, Italy
Publication Title: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
Abstract: Objective: The complex nature of Parkinson's disease (PD) makes difficult to rate its severity, mainly based on the visual inspection of motor impairments. Wearable sensors have been demonstrated to help overcoming such a difficulty, by providing objective measures of motor abnormalities. However, up to now, those sensors have been used on advanced PD patients with evident motor impairment. As a novelty, here we report the impact of wearable sensors in the evaluation of motor abnormalities in newly diagnosed, untreated, namely de novo, patients. Methods: A network of wearable sensors was used to measure motor capabilities, in 30 de novo PD patients and 30 healthy subjects, while performing five motor tasks. Measurement data were used to determine motor features useful to highlight impairments and were compared with the corresponding clinical scores. Three classifiers were used to differentiate PD from healthy subjects. Results: Motor features gathered from wearable sensors showed a high degree of significance in discriminating the early untreated de novo PD patients from the healthy subjects, with 95% accuracy. The rates of severity obtained from the measured features are partially in agreement with the clinical scores, with some highlighted, though justified, exceptions. Conclusion: Our findings support the feasibility of adopting wearable sensors in the detection of motor anomalies in early, untreated, PD patients. Significance: This work demonstrates that subtle motor impairments, occurring in de novo patients, can be evidenced by means of wearable sensors, providing clinicians with instrumental tools as suitable supports for early diagnosis, and subsequent management.
Author Keywords: IMU;machine learning;motion analysis;parkinson's disease;signal processing;wearable technology
IEEE Terms: Task analysis;Wearable sensors;Biomedical measurement;Parkinson's disease;Atmospheric measurements;Particle measurements

Document Title: What Engineering Technology Could Do for Quality of Life in Parkinson's Disease: A Review of Current Needs and Opportunities
Authors: J. A. Stamford; P. N. Schmidt; K. E. Friedl
Author Affiliations: Parkinson's Movement, The Cure Parkinson's Trust, London, U.K.; National Parkinson's Foundation, Miami, FL, USA; AIMBE
Publication Title: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
Abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) involves well-known motor symptoms such as tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and altered gait, but there are also nonlocomotory motor symptoms (e.g., changes in handwriting and speech) and even nonmotor symptoms (e.g., disrupted sleep, depression) that can be measured, monitored, and possibly better managed through activity-based monitoring technologies. This will enhance quality of life (QoL) in PD through improved self-monitoring and also provide information that could be shared with a healthcare provider to help better manage treatment. Until recently, nonmotor symptoms (“soft signs”) had been generally overlooked in clinical management, yet these are of primary importance to patients and their QoL. Day-to-day variability of the condition, the high variability in symptoms between patients, and the isolated snapshots of a patient in periodic clinic visits make better monitoring essential to the proper management of PD. Continuously monitored patterns of activity, social interactions, and daily activities could provide a rich source of information on status changes, guiding self-correction and clinical management. The same tools can be useful in earlier detection of PD and will improve clinical studies. Remote medical communications in the form of telemedicine, sophisticated tracking of medication use, and assistive technologies that directly compensate for disease-related challenges are examples of other near-term technology solutions to PD problems. Ultimately, a sensor technology is not good if it is not used. The Parkinson's community is a sophisticated early adopter of useful technologies and a group for which engineers can provide near-term gratifying benefits.
Author Keywords: review article;activity;nonmotor symptoms;cognition;depression;sleep quality;exercise;patient perspective;Activity;cognition;depression;exercise;nonmotor symptoms;patient perspective;review article;sleep quality
IEEE Terms: Cognition;Sleep;Biomedical monitoring;Parkinson's disease;Mood

Document Title: Impact of Surgical History on Parkinson's Disease Progression
Authors: V. Majhi; S. Paul; G. Saha
Author Affiliations: Department of Biomedical Engineering, North-Eastern Hill University, Shillong, India; Department of Biomedical Engineering, North-Eastern Hill University, Shillong, India; Department of Information Technology, North-Eastern Hill University, Shillong, India
Publication Title: 2022 IEEE Delhi Section Conference (DELCON)
Abstract: The records of surgical history are seen in approximately 89.74% closer to records of health records of patients with Parkinson's disease. However, compared to the control group, this ratio does not show very significant differences. However, one of the straightforward ideas we can get from this ratio is that for every 100 PD patients, 89 PD patients are undergoing at least one surgery in their lifetime. Therefore, it is essential to find the relationship between surgical history and the occurrence of PD. In this study, 12 surgical history-related questions were asked, classified into a PD group and a control group, and tested for gender (Male and Female). Significant participation in the surgical history of PD is seen, and in most cases, cranial or brain surgery has an 81% to 85% chance of developing PD.

Document Title: Capsule Networks with a Self-Attention Mechanism for Classification of Parkinson's Disase from Tremor
Authors: R. Ban
Author Affiliations: School of Information Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Publication Title: 2025 5th International Conference on Consumer Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICCECE)
Abstract: The traditional diagnosis of Parkinson's disease (PD)primarily relies on the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale and the clinical experience of physicians, leading to significant subjectivity in diagnosis. To address this issue, we employ sensor systems to collect tremor parameters from PD patients and analyzed these collected data using traditional machine learning algorithms, providing an objective and quantitative diagnosis for PD. To obtain more comprehensive features, this study adopts the PKG wearable device to extract 12 tremor features from 100 PD patients, along with recording 9 scale-based features and 3 demographic characteristics. Furthermore, to overcome the issues of low accuracy and poor generalization ability of traditional machine learning methods, we propose a capsule network integrated with a self-attention mechanism (SA-CapsNet) for classifying and predicting early stage and moderate to advanced stage stage PD patients. We also utilize the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) to improve the model's ability to generalize. Lastly, The Shapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) model is introduced to improve the interpretability of the predictive model, and feature analysis is conducted to identify the main factors influencing classification and prediction. Experimental results demonstrate that the SA-CapsNet method for PD can achieve an accuracy of 92.31%, precision of 82.19%, recall of 91.23%, specificity of 80.00%, and an F1 score of 85.25%. Therefore, the proposed SACapsNet method not only exhibits good generalization ability for small sample sizes and imbalanced class data but also effectively assists physicians in staging the severity of PD.
Author Keywords: Parkinson's Disease (PD);Wearable Sensor Devices;Rating Scale;Self-Attention Mechanism;Capsule Network
IEEE Terms: Support vector machines;Accuracy;Parkinson's disease;Medical services;Predictive models;Feature extraction;Sensor systems;Data mining;Wearable devices;Wearable sensors
